column3: This is a block with 1 set cell

column18: The light yellow cells are the block's border
column19: The bright yellow cells are the block's frame
column20: Everything inside the border is the block's canvas
column21: The block's canvas can have set cells like this one
Or empty cell's like the cells around this one

column18: Nearby set cells on a block's canvas like this one

column19: and this one form a "cell cluster" on the canvas

column6: Two blocks near each other like this one
column10: and this one can overlap and form a "block cluster"
block clusters can either have "linked" blocks like the ones above with orange cells
column13: or "locked" blocks like this block cluster with red cells since they are closer together

column19: You can move cells around by selecting a canvas cell and hitting Ctrl+ArrowKey
You can also select nearby blocks by selecting a canvas cell and hitting Alt+ArrowKey
column25: You can also create a grid cell by selecting an empty cell and pressing F3
column26: Or you can enter an existing grid cell (one that starts with a comma) by selecting it and hitting F3
column27: Try selecting the cell to the right and hitting F3, and to get back to this grid just hit Esc
column28:
